messages.subject: RE: Tameshigiri clean up
messages.msgSnippet: Sorry for the lack of precision.  I had a couple of e-mails for more details.  Actually Arm & Hammer baking soda.  About a heaping tablespoon to 350 to 400
messages.messageBody:
Sorry for the lack of precision. I had a couple of e-mails for more
details. Actually Arm & Hammer baking soda. About a heaping tablespoon to
350 to 400 milliliters or a little over 12 oz (the amout in a standard soft
drink can). The solution is alkaline and should make your fingers feel
slippery.

Rick

-----Original Message-----
From: Hill, Richard
To: 'token_kenkyu_kai@... '
Cc: 'TOKEN '; 'nihontostudy '; 'nihonto@yahoogroups.com '
Sent: 3/28/2004 3:12 PM
Subject: RE: Tameshigiri clean up

I have tried a number of ways to clean blades after cutting. Here us a
good one. A soft cloth with one end soaked in a solution of baking
powder, the other dry. After your cut, wipe the blade with the wet end
to remove debris, then the the dry end. I follow with the uchiko and
choji oil. The alkaline solution wil prevent staining and is similiar
to the solution used by polishers.

Rick Hill
